Comments_List: Critical assessment of black urban life

One of the greatest takeaways concerned basic sociological method: some of the best analyses are produced from synthesizing primary source accounts and demographic data.  The course really provided thought-provoking insights on black American family structure as a result of a historical evolution spanning the entire 20th century.

This course equipped me with general understandings of African Americans' narrative in America, and I learned the currently held ideas of why Black people have higher rates of joblessness and single-parent households in comparison to white people. I also learned about Professor Jaynes' contrasting perspective through reading his manuscript.
The readings are short and extremely interesting. There were few assignments for the course but they were sometimes assigned only a week in advance which was a pain.
I felt that this course provided me with interesting insight into the topic, and though it started off slow, I grew to be fascinated with the information taught.
Yes, it provides a different view on the black community.
I would recommend.  Professor Jaynes ran the course in an engaging and richly conversational style, which helped really make the semester a memorable one.

I would recommend this course to a student who is specifically interested in African Americans' position in American society today and understanding the roots of this position. It is a very specific topic, so I would only recommend to someone who has interest in the question the course intends to answer.
